awd_titl_txt: Early Engagement for Entering Freshman Science Majors
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, the "Early Engagement for Entering Freshman Science Majors" project is providing support to low-income students with demonstrated financial need and academic promise to succeed in STEM disciplines at the University of New Orleans. The project is funding 18 scholarships over 5 years for students who are pursuing bachelor's degrees in Computer Sciences, Chemistry, and Biological Sciences. This project will explore learning environments to increase the persistence and graduation rates of STEM majors at a highly diverse institution in an effort to enhance the US STEM workforce pool.  The project goals are to improve academic outcomes for STEM students by providing a network of comprehensive support, engagement activities, and internships/research; to increase career and graduate school success through mentoring and career training; and to increase student confidence and preparedness to pursue a career in a scientific field. The unique contribution of this project arises from the testing of a combination of new and old interventions implemented on campus that will allow the research team to infer which work the best for persistence and graduation of students from low-income but academically talented backgrounds.  

This project will utilize several strategies to facilitate the success of the student scholars, including: (1) Providing comprehensive guidance by faculty mentors, peer mentors, and existing enrollment support staff; (2) Enrolling students in common sections of student support classes; (3) Providing comprehensive engagement opportunities in a flexible manner, including academic year enrichment activities; (4) Following the progress of each student and compare it with the progress of similar students not in the S-STEM program; and (5) Using the results of internal and external formative and summative evaluation to develop future models for improved student success. By recruiting prospective scholars from Upward Bound participants, local high school students from low income backgrounds, and other qualified entering freshmen from additional locations, this project will increase understanding of how components of this program might have the most effect on student persistence and graduation.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The University of New Orleans (UNO) S-STEM program was designed to increase the support for low-income, academically talented students in Biology, Chemistry and Computer Sciences through scholarships to prepare them for entry into the STEM workforce or a STEM graduate program upon receipt of a BS degree.  The project goals were: 1) to improve academic progress, retention and graduation rates of STEM students by providing a network of comprehensive support, engagement activities, and internships/research; 2) to increase career and graduate school success through mentoring and career training; 3) to increase student confidence and preparedness to pursue a career in a scientific field.

 

 In order to accomplish these goals, we recruited, mentored, and followed the progress of 24 entering freshmen STEM scholars in two cohorts (2018, 2019) and of 9 juniors/transfer students in a 3rd cohort (2021).  Of the 33 Scholars, 73% of the students supported reported as being first-generation college students.  Fourteen (42%) were from underrepresented minorities (African-American, Native American or Hispanic) and 19 (58%) were female. The project utilized scholarships (up to $10000/year, based upon financial need), cohort-based activities, peer mentoring, faculty mentoring, and other student support activities to improve student progress, retention, and graduation rates. Students were also connected with Career Services for workshops on resumé preparation as well as how to find a job or an internship.

 

Intellectual merit: All incoming freshman participated in a 5-day STEM Scholars bridge camp just prior to enrolling in the Fall. This bridge camp consists of math or biology lectures to expose students to the pace of college work, real tests, and study skills.  Cohort building and college success skills are emphasized in this bridge camp. Our data from 2018-2019 bridge camps show that the average persistence rate for STEM camp attendees vs non-camp STEM majors was at least 10% higher each year, strongly suggesting the camp had an impact on our S-STEM students that participated. We have continued to utitlize this bridge camp as a tool to increase retention of freshman STEM students.

 

The graduation rate for all S-STEM-supported scholars was 73%, markedly higher than the graduation rate for the matched control group students (52%).  It is important to note that most of the project was conducted in an environment that was challenging for students nationwide and particularly difficult for the city of New Orleans. While the disruption caused by the Covid-19 pandemic, starting in the project’s 2nd year, was a worldwide phenomenon, New Orleans also had to contend with Hurricane Ida in Fall 2021. Interviews with S-STEM students suggest that the scholarship funding, the faculty mentoring, and internships made the biggest impact.

 

Broader impacts: Overall, we successfully graduated 24 STEM students (12 Computer Sciences, 8 Biological Sciences, and 4 Chemistry majors), graduating 6 more students than planned in the original project. After these students graduated, a follow-up survey was conducted with a 73% survey completion rate.  Of the students who completed the survey, 21% were enrolled in a graduate program or other STEM-related program.  63% were employed in a STEM-related field upon graduation. The remainder were actively looking for employment related to their degree (16%).  The students who were employed had found jobs at companies located in Louisiana as well as many other states, contributing significantly to the STEM workforce.

 


Last Modified: 01/30/2025
Modified by: Wendy M Schluchter

In order to accomplish these goals, we recruited, mentored, and followed the progress of 24 entering freshmen STEM scholars in two cohorts (2018, 2019) and of 9 juniors/transfer students in a 3rd cohort (2021). Of the 33 Scholars, 73% of the students supported reported as being first-generation college students. Interviews with S-STEM students suggest that the scholarship funding, the faculty mentoring, and internships made the biggest impact.

The remainder were actively looking for employment related to their degree (16%). The students who were employed had found jobs at companies located in Louisiana as well as many other states, contributing significantly to the STEM workforce.
